{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3366285,"name":"","username":"Echoing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/echoing/{size}/222017_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T08:22:52.821Z","cooked":"

Our team has been lately working on our offseason robot design, and we kind of want to implement the 2056 style and add an over the bumper intake to it. However, we’re not sure what frame size we should use. We can reduce the frame diameter to around 600mm600mm in theory considering the electronics’ layout. But is smaller drivetrain necessarily better? I suppose with a smaller robot comes lighter weight and easier passing through defense, but does it have a significant tactical advantage in this year’s game?
﻿
The reason why we are concerned about smaller drivetrains is that we picked 650mm650mm this year with an Unqualified Quokkas design. While it is a relatively low CG bot, we’ve experienced the lighter front side of our robot tipping off the ground when accelerating. Since we’ll be pushing the height of our offseason robot to the hight limit (700mm) according to 2056’s design, and want the robot to pass through defense easily, it’s quite hard to determine the frame diameter (600mm600mm all the way to 750mm750mm).
﻿
Actually I think this is a rarely talked but fundamental part of the design of a robot. So let discussion begin!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T08:22:52.821Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":141,"reads":1079,"readers_count":1078,"score":935.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61702,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6940 Former Co-Captain and Chief Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/1","custom_user_title":"6940 Former Co-Captain and Chief Engineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3366300,"name":"TheRohan","username":"TheRohan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therohan/{size}/223304_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T10:59:40.032Z","cooked":"

You can also look at 2910. Super small build as well. I think it is generally better because you’re more versatile, however it takes a lot of really good engineering to be able to pull off that compact size without sacrificing preformance

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T10:59:40.032Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":990,"readers_count":989,"score":243.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"TheRohan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24101,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Impact Mentor - 201 & 488, Alumni - 201"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/2","custom_user_title":"Impact Mentor - 201 & 488, Alumni - 201","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366305,"name":"Evan Kruger","username":"flightpath24","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/flightpath24/{size}/168117_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T11:19:59.708Z","cooked":"

Ultimately, it’s up to the team and the design what size is best. The smallest bot in North Carolina this year was also one of the best (7763). However, some teams like Madtown (1323) choose to build max frame perimeter max weight robots almost every year because they deem that necessary to maximize performance.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T11:19:59.708Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":947,"readers_count":946,"score":249.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Evan Kruger","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51945,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8738A | xRC | MoSim"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/3","custom_user_title":"8738A | xRC | MoSim","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366369,"name":"Silas","username":"SilasR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/silasr/{size}/185275_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T13:46:18.996Z","cooked":"

There are a lot of tradeoffs by reducing frame perimeter, but as you said you need to be careful about COG, as with a smaller drive base the more likely you are to be tippy. 2910 tipped at chezy champs in 2021, despite being a pretty short robot.

IMO a smaller frame is not really worth it in most scenarios unless its for endgame.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T13:46:33.318Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":834,"readers_count":833,"score":221.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Silas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DT9nbXh1f8w&t=118s","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":60}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51263,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366388,"name":"Doug Frisk","username":"Doug_Frisk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/doug_frisk/{size}/125193_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T14:28:40.628Z","cooked":"

Yes. The relative advantages of building small are manifold.

The advantages of building large are that you are heavier, slower, and clumsier.

I keep telling teams up here that they want to design top down, figure out what your intake and scoring mechanisms are going to do and then build the frame just large enough to accommodate them instead of building a big platform and slapping other stuff on once you’ve decided what you want.

Pretty much everyone ignores me though.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T14:28:40.628Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":764,"readers_count":763,"score":262.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Doug Frisk","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22789,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The one with the practice field, Duluth RPC"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/5","custom_user_title":"The one with the practice field, Duluth RPC","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366395,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T14:43:39.708Z","cooked":"
Doug_Frisk:

I keep telling teams up here that they want to design top down, figure out what your intake and scoring mechanisms are going to do and then build the frame just large enough to accommodate

Hmm, this is an interesting philosophy that I don’t know if I agree with. My thoughts on FIRST over the last few years have been that build timeline is everything. What I’m pushing our team towards is deciding on drivetrain dimensions before the season, and only changing them if the game really justifies it, so that we can start building a drivetrain day 2 and have a driving robot mid-week 2. This would also allow us to have a prebuilt practice chassis with identical dimensions to our final chassis.

The philosophy here is that FRC is not about building a perfect robot, but about building an imperfect robot fast so you can improve it.

We are not as capable in up front design as other teams so perhaps that’s driving my thoughts. We also don’t have the capacity to build a separate alpha and final bot, IMO.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T14:43:39.708Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":701,"readers_count":700,"score":260.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366398,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T14:54:13.570Z","cooked":"

Completely agree with this mentality and perspective. Building small has a number of not-insignificant benefits:

Your robot will be harder to hit by other robots. This is especially important if you intend to be an offensive robot. This makes you inherently more difficult to defend.

You are less likely to be in your alliance’s way. Especially important in games with small gamepiece acquition areas (2019, 2023, 2024) or small endgame space (2022, 2024).

Your robot rotates faster. Having the wheels closer together means the rate at which your robot can rotate is faster. This is amplified because the rotational interia of a small robot is less, meaning you can accelerate rotationally more quickly.

Your main base structure will weigh less, giving more weight that can be dedicated to mechanisms, or to have a generally lighter robot. If you decide to have a lighter robot you get the extra benefit of a higher possible robot acceleration.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T14:54:13.570Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":629,"readers_count":628,"score":165.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22789,"username":"Doug_Frisk","name":"Doug Frisk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/doug_frisk/{size}/125193_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/7","custom_user_title":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366408,"name":"Elliot S","username":"ElliotS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elliots/{size}/177628_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T15:15:48.555Z","cooked":"
SilasR:

2910 tipped at chezy champs in 2021

They said they now have a rule that the minimum size of the drive base is 26x26 for this reason

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T15:15:48.555Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":582,"readers_count":581,"score":166.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Elliot S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50070,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Probably CADing | 2877 LigerBots Alum-Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/8","custom_user_title":"Probably CADing | 2877 LigerBots Alum-Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3366409,"name":"Adam Fleming","username":"AdamF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamf/{size}/234717_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-20T15:16:41.463Z","cooked":"

I think as an offseason project, building as small as possible is a great way to see how to efficiently package everything. Those lessons will carry forward to any bigger robot, so I’d say go for it!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-20T15:16:41.463Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":579,"readers_count":578,"score":160.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Adam Fleming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41952,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/9","custom_user_title":"FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3369810,"name":"Saber_8871","username":"tyron256","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyron256/{size}/177261_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-22T19:07:54.933Z","cooked":"

We went with 23" by 23" this year for a couple of reasons.

  1. we wanted to be able to better harmonize with other teams
  2. since we fly to most events, we needed to have the robot be compact enough and light enough to not be overweight or oversized when flying as checked luggage
  3. we prioritized being fast and light over being a heavy battering ram.

Lessons learned: while the students could probably chime in better that i can, it was a great expereince in learning how to be efficient in space. Our robot packed more function into a smaller space than most other robots had over an entire design. it is HARD to efficiently manage space without sacrificing function (we had a few issues, some of which still persist that prevented us from operating at our best).

All in all, we will be doing it again mostly because of number 2 above, but really it depends on what the game is in terms of being strategically small (although its always easier to squeeze past defenders as a small bot)

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-22T19:07:54.933Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":524,"readers_count":523,"score":124.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Saber_8871","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7167,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3370017,"name":"Totally out of touch","username":"AdamHeard","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamheard/{size}/195262_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-22T20:59:04.981Z","cooked":"

Going small in the name of speed can be useful, but I would not compromise reliability or functionality before doing so.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-22T20:59:04.981Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":470,"readers_count":469,"score":244.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Totally out of touch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3609,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3372070,"name":"Tyler","username":"Tyler_S","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyler_s/{size}/186371_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T13:21:58.816Z","cooked":"
Doug_Frisk:

I keep telling teams up here that they want to design top down, figure out what your intake and scoring mechanisms are going to do and then build the frame just large enough to accommodate them instead of building a big platform and slapping other stuff on once you’ve decided what you want.

We followed this design method almost to the letter this year! Once we had decided to go with a Quokka-style robot, we started figuring out critical dimensions. For a 14" note, we figured an 18" intake would be a good width, a compromise between large enough to be effective and not too large. For an 18" intake, we roughed out that a 22" wide robot would be ideal. We then calculated that a 28" long robot would be needed to fit the arm style, and started work on assembling our drive base. Compared to our previous robots, this is by far our smallest and lightest.

FRC 2846 FireBears | 2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance

20240120_0938571920×1081 471 KB

Don’t talk to me or my son ever again

While we didn’t quite hit out 18" wide intake goal due to packaging constraints (we only got 16"), we are fully on board the small robot train. Smaller, lighter, faster to accelerate, faster to rotate, and a lot more benefits mentioned here.

One big benefit we had with being small was our ability to do a 4-piece amp-side auto without touching the center notes:

image893×844 70.8 KB

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T13:21:58.816Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":404,"readers_count":403,"score":130.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Tyler","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-2846-firebears-2024-build-thread-open-alliance/446950/7","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 2846 FireBears | 2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/8/f/8f2d43a56de7e77d7b81ad758af3bf6faa1f679a.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23205,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor, Alumni, and Volunteer"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/12","custom_user_title":"Mentor, Alumni, and Volunteer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3372083,"name":"Owen Murtha","username":"owenmurt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/owenmurt/{size}/225684_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T13:36:30.026Z","cooked":"

I really wish every design team could hear this, because it’s some of the best advice my team received this year. We used a top-down design process this year, and as a result, we designed (probably) the most mechanically sophisticated robot in our team’s recent history. It really does make it a lot easier to design and package everything on your robot, so I really wish people were more aware of it.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T13:36:30.026Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":351,"readers_count":350,"score":85.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Owen Murtha","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22789,"username":"Doug_Frisk","name":"Doug Frisk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/doug_frisk/{size}/125193_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58372,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAD Gremlin"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/13","custom_user_title":"CAD Gremlin","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3372114,"name":"Andy Mundell","username":"suPURDUEperAndy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/supurdueperandy/{size}/266209_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T14:18:25.092Z","cooked":"

We ended up at max perimeter this year because of the choice to pull the note between our swerve modules and to shoot through an elevator mechanism. We would have loved to be smaller and lighter, but our robot archetype wouldn’t allow it. We were very happy with our decision, and I’m glad we didn’t compromise our design choices just to be small.

I guess my advice would be to make the robot as big as your mechanisms require, but no bigger. That being said, having a wide intake is awesome! The increased tolerance for acquiring notes, especially in autonomous, is very helpful.

That might make it easier but it’s not required. Our frame perimeter was 120" and we had a couple amp side autos that went out to the centre line, and none of those touched the 3 close notes.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T14:21:59.774Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":306,"readers_count":305,"score":61.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23205,"username":"Tyler_S","name":"Tyler","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyler_s/{size}/186371_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3372121,"name":"","username":"Ben_Martin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ben_martin/{size}/213340_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T14:23:35.485Z","cooked":"

We went small for speed, but it ended up being more useful for avoiding source defense.

We’d probably do it again. Packaging and serviceability are sometimes tricky though.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T14:23:35.485Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":60.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6001,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3372123,"name":"","username":"aven","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aven/{size}/261990_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T14:24:36.918Z","cooked":"

Due to our limited resources, we usually have a fully built swerve chassis before build season even starts. The advantage of this is that we don’t need to spend valuable build season time working on the drivetrain, and all the swerve code has already been written and tested. The only downside to this is that we don’t have flexibility with the drivetrain dimensions; we usually just go with a near-max size chassis so that we have room to work with during the build season though.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T14:24:36.918Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":302,"readers_count":301,"score":60.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":463450,"topic_slug":"is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62505,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2374 strategy/vice design lead"},"post_url":"/t/is-relatively-smaller-robots-generally-better/463450/17","custom_user_title":"2374 strategy/vice design lead","reactions":[{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3372128,"name":"Ankur Raghavan","username":"Ankur-Raghavan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ankur-raghavan/{size}/207141_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T14:29:50.274Z","cooked":"

I think the reason that small bots do well is that the teams that have the resources and the want to optimize their packaging as much as possible, have the resources to build a good bot. Teams who are less likely to build a good bot often go max size to ensure they have space if things don’t work out.
